content: a crafter @dm Scottie bringing another project today this is a pretty cool
project and I say that about all projects but this one is pretty cool too
it's a really easy way another alternate way to make torches torch posts and I
also going to show you a torch span so let's go to the table and we'll start
crafting those easy torches and stands so here I have some toothpicks and these
are to fix that sandwich toothpicks with cellophane on the ends right you see I
got some blue and orangish colors and I'm gonna use these as the basis for my
torch I got these at Dollar Store this pack of dollars store for a dollar okay
so now I got my toothpick with the cellophane here I've got a bunch of them
and I really like that on the end a route looks like a fire if we can doctor
that up a bit so I'm going to use a yellow a nice bright yellow and a red
and I'm gonna water the yellow down a bit and put it on the toothpicks and
then the same with the red I'll put that on there too but I'm watering it down
not putting on a full strength now I'm gonna use a black and a dark brown and
I'm going to put around the where the fire meets the torch I'll make that a
little bit black okay so it's like it's kind of burning there and then I'm gonna
use the brown to fill in the torch I'll just leave the end undone so now I'll
start putting them on this tray just so they won't stick to the paper okay so
I'm just painting these torches Brown and I'll just lay in there to dry it'll
be all set so I want to take this and I'm going to measure it so I'm going to
measure an inch and a half and that's where I'm going to cut the torch off
okay so I have a flat bottom instead of a pointed bottom all right there we go
they're all set now I'm going to detail a little bit further with a tan I'm just
gonna water it down a bit and just kind of go on those torch posts there and
I'll just do the same to all the torch posts so just to give some variation in
color and there we go it's not want to do some
holders for these I'm going to use my washer technique so get some washers out
and I'm gonna use six of these so I would use my hot glue gun and I'm going
to glue them to the the paper just to hold them down okay so you guys are
pricing anything this technique before just fill in the washer alright so it's
doesn't look just like a flat washer there so it looks more like ground and
then I'm gonna go around the washer kind of taper it so it'll they kind of taper
the edge and this will firmly stick it to the paper but you'll see what i'm
gonna do here next okay so i got that i'll detailed around the edge nice and
varied so it doesn't just look like a round washer now while these are glue to
the paper I'm gonna use my craft goop and I'll glue some beads to these these
are gonna be the stands for the torches okay I like these stands because I'm
doing some primitive awesome do some primitive torches and I'm using these
beads that look kind of like native II looking I don't know if that's a word
but I used it okay so now I'm going to glue the these round beads to the to the
washers here with the craft goop and you see there's that hole in the center
where the bead would go through on this dough on the strings and I'm going to
glue the second part on top of that and I'll make sure that it's that that part
is open so I'm using the toothpick I stuck it in the top to make sure that
it's clear right because I want the torch to be able to go in this vessel
alright so let's keep just assemble all these and then the same I make sure that
that top is clear and now they've dried I'm going to remove them from this paper
okay so I'm just gonna cut them up a little bit with the scissors and then I
will just essentially just rip them off the paper okay there's gonna be some
stuff left I'll just cut it off with the scissors and I'll have a nice tapered
base there with weight from the washer now that's pre-printed these base black
flat black now he's a dark-brown wash and I'm gonna
wash all these with the dark brown so I'm making sure that I get the base also
as well as the torch holder so I get a lot of my hands but hey it washes off
right so those are all ready and dried up now I've got a kind of earth brown
I'm going to use that to do the to do the base just a little bit of a
different Brown there and I'm going to use this kind of coffee
to paint the holder now that's dried up now I want to use a metallic black you
know and the reason for this is kinda it looks how it looks like a lacquer that's
on the wood and I like that technique all right there we go so we'll let that
dry up so here we go I have a village set up with our nice torches and I think
they look really great so our adventurers come in and let me show you
the scale to these adventures so there's the adventurer standing next to it the
perfect scale for these adventures we'll give you a closer look the torch holder
and the torch looking really great I like how the light really goes through
that cellophane and makes it look kind of luminescent then you know we got the
nice torch holder fits right in there easily so let me show you one last thing
I did with these I think is a really fun idea or move mr. Roderick up here and I
could pull the torch out of the torch holder and the character could hold it
so you can see here I have a base for the torch and basically just took a
small washer and some hot glue and glued it to that and then you can put it right
next to the character and they can move around with it you can kind of simulate
that they're holding a torch or you could even just put it on their base
like this the base is small and the torch you could just do that if it the
character will fit on the character base so there we go there's our easy
cellophane torches hey crafters I hope you find these up
it's helpful and informative if you do make sure you share these days with your
friends also we have a Facebook page and a forum so make sure you join those if
you're really interested in this kind of crafting there's all kinds of ideas and
techniques on there and make sure to give your old Scotty a like
if you did like the video and last but not least to a 4-bit craft
